message.content:
cs.PL, cs.LO, cs.DS, cs.AI, cs.SE 

This paper is likely to belong to the Programming Languages (cs.PL) sub-category as it introduces an extension to Prolog, a logic programming language. It also discusses source-level transformations and abstract machine adaptations, which are relevant to programming language research. 

It could also belong to the Logic in Computer Science (cs.LO) sub-category as it deals with logic variables and their unification. 

The paper's focus on algorithms such as graph coloring and minimum spanning tree suggests that it could belong to the Data Structures and Algorithms (cs.DS) sub-category. 

The use of logic variables for global information exchange and the discussion of their usefulness in solving problems suggests that the paper could also belong to the Artificial Intelligence (cs.AI) sub-category. 

Finally, the paper's discussion of program transformations and extensions to existing functionality suggests that it could belong to the Software Engineering (cs.SE) sub-category.
